Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Ian Johnston of Boston University to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at Kyoto University's Institute for Chemical Research in Kyoto. The project title is "Developing Latent Genotypes for Genome-Wide Association Studies." The host scientist is Professor Hiroshi Mamitsuka.

This research project rigorously vets a new technique for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) that combines a Bayesian statistical model with a novel concept of a "latent genotype" in an attempt to: formally address rare variants and linkage disequilibrium in GWAS data; and to exploit the underlying structure of single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to then identify associations between SNPs and genes and diseases. The latent genotypes are obtained by transforming the original genotypes in such a way so as to correct for the strong correlation present in the data. In order to justify the use of the latent genotypes in GWAS, an additional goal of the project is to conduct a comparative analysis of current Bayesian and non-Bayesian methods using the original genotypes versus the latent genotypes. The product of this research project is an extensive comparative analysis that first investigates the usefulness of the latent genotypes and then investigates the usefulness of the novel Bayesian statistical model for GWAS, as well as software that implements the proposed model.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the software to be produced by this research project can be used by industry professionals as well as in teaching examples. In particular, the cross-fertilization of ideas between statisticians and geneticists would be especially fruitful in establishing groundwork for future mutual projects as well as for the networks of communication that are ultimately necessary to achieve the overall goals of genetic studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research project, I developed and tested a newly proposed statistical model for the task of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) where the goal is to select which numerically encoded pieces of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) are associated with a particular human disease. My proposed model leverages information about human genes and uniquely allows for the probability that pieces of DNA are associated with a disease to be weighted by their proximity to relevant genes. I collaborated with experts in biology at the Institute of Chemical Research within Kyoto University to discuss and refine my proposed relationship between these pieces of DNA, also known as single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), and genes. Our discussion led to the idea of using text-mining algorithms and network analysis methods to quantify the relevance of a gene with respect to a particular disease for my model in a principled way by considering metrics like the number of times that a gene appears in the literature about that disease.

In order to compare the performance of my proposed model to a handful of other popular models that have previously been applied in the GWAS literature, I conducted a large simulation study on a subset of real SNP data on chromosome 1 provided by the Wellcome Trust Case Control Consortium (WTCCC). Afterwards I also conducted a case study analysis on real data concerning the presence or absence of Rheumatoid Arthritis in the WTCCC dataset. Using the new model, I was able not only to recapitulate results that were obtained when using other simpler models as reported in the literature but also to highlight interesting SNPs that have otherwise only been found when pooling information across studies in meta-analyses.

As broader impacts of my research, in July I presented a poster of my work at the International Workshop on Bioinformatics and Systems Biology at Kyoto University, and in August I gave a talk on my work at the International Workshop on Machine Learning and Applications to Biology at Hokkaido University. After returning to Boston University (BU), I finished compiling all of the results and submitted a draft of a paper that details our method and findings to the Annals of Applied Statistics journal. In the beginning of the 2013 fall semester at BU, I gave another talk on my work at the BU-Keio Summer Workshop as well as a seminar to undergraduate and graduate students about both my recent work in Japan and the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes for U.S. Graduate Students (EAPSI) program including how to apply to next year’s program. Since then, I have also begun mentoring an undergraduate student at BU on the topics of Bayesian statistics and its applications to GWAS. We are currently putting together a software package in R that will allow researchers around the world to easily apply our model to their own datasets.
